07 Nov 2019, 09:00 by Johannes Morken
In many countries, women are doubly persecuted - both because of their faith and their gender. In Iraq, IS attacked Jesidians - the men were killed, women were drawn as sex slaves and our commodity in the caliphate.
Still, 3000 women are not set free. The surviving host tried to stack his legs again. But there are no traces of any court cases following the genocide.
There are also strong reports from other areas. For a long time, Christian women were first and foremost victims of persecution: they became widows when men were killed, or they became miserable with the care of children when men were imprisoned.
But in recent years, Christian women have also been directly attacked by terrorist groups such as IS, and by al-Shabaab and Boko Haram in parts of Africa (and by the so-called Christian medical terrorist group Lord's Resistance Army and; red.mrk).
"Mary's" rape
Helene Fisher of Open Doors International has for 12 years studied how women are persecuted both for their faith and their gender. At one time she was heavily involved in work in the Central African Republic. There she met many raped women, often they were raped by gangs.
Fisher tells of "Mary", married and mother of two. A militant, Islamist group came to the village. The family hid. When the famine trough, "Maria" and the man took the chance to leave the children to fetch food out in the fields.
As the militia approached, "Mary" asked the man to escape. She was sure that neither boat would be able to get away. The militia demanded to get the white man left. "Mary" said she was alone. "Then you have to pay the price!" Was the answer. Mary saw the gang sign. Bloody and disgraceful every woman lying in the field.
The man had hidden himself - he looked like her, but was without a chance to stop the wrongdoing. He took the injured and broken woman home. But after a couple of days, the man didn't cope. The page "Mary" has not seen him. Ho missed the men. The children lost their father. "Maria" was ejected from the village as "urine".
There is no doubt that the militia attacked her because she was a Christian. There was a ruined family.
Demolish society
In other cities, extremists are loathing women from other groups who want to crush them. The strategy was and is clear. By attacking women, they will break down the foundation of society's attacks.
The Christian village of "Mary" could break with the strongly ingrained notion of "impure". They could have said that shame was only on those who ruled, not on Mary. She had found herself in grave danger of saving the man. Mary was not, the village could say, the lowest of the gate - she was, on the other hand, a Christ-like driver who wanted to protect the family. The village could tell the children that their mother was a hero. Open Doors has, says Fisher, launched a trauma treatment and family therapy program to help Christian communities cope with attacks altogether.
Resistance
There is little research on persecution due to threat and gender. It may be to blame that much of the violence against women - from extremist groups, but also from the family of women - takes place in the pay. It is not easy to research what you do not see.
But there is also active resistance to seeing contexts. Many who study or fight for equality for women internationally do not accept that women are being pursued twice - both for their gender and for their faith. Activists and bureaucrats believe religion is an important cause of lack of equality.
The UN's former Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Threats, Heiner Bielefeldt, put this to words in the 2013 report on the threat of life and belief in the world. He wrote that there has been a widespread notion that trusts and equality are human rights that are in sharp contrast to each other, even though they are both listed in human rights statements and conventions. This erroneous impression can, according to the UN Reporter, prevent women from being protected.

Together with Danish colleagues, we have been commissioned by foreign ministries in Norway and Denmark for the past year to conduct international work to study women's equality and gender equality in light of four of the UN's goals for health, the rule of law, education and climate. The report comes around New Year. Then the UN report comes out in the New Year.
